    • Method Detail

      • addMonthsRespectingDayOfMonth

        public static java.util.Date addMonthsRespectingDayOfMonth(java.util.Date date,
                                           int iMonths)
        Adds the specified (signed) amount of months to the given date. For example, to subtract 5 months from the current date, you can achieve it by calling: addMonths( date, -5 ). The important difference between this method and DateUtil#addMonths() is that this method will identify if the current date is at the end of a month, and potentially larger than a future date's end of month. We want to avoid situations where the day of month changes as part of a series of calls to this method.

        For example, DateUtil.addMonths would return the following series:

        Jan 30, Feb 28, Mar 28, etc

        This method would return: Jan 30, Feb 28, Mar 30, etc

        Parameters:
        date - The time.
        iMonths - The amount of months to add.
        Returns:
        A new date with the months added.

      • hash

        public static java.lang.String hash(java.lang.String str)
        Computes the cryptographic hash of a string.

        See CryptUtil.hashPasswordString(String)

        Parameters:
        str - the string to hash
        Returns:
        the cryptographic hash of the string

      • generateRandomIDFromCurrentTime

        public static java.lang.String generateRandomIDFromCurrentTime(int length)
        Generates a random string of numbers of the specified length. In order to come close to ensuring uniqueness, the system clock's current time, in milliseconds, is used as the basis for the ID. The current time is then reversed so that the most significant digits are at the end of the ID, and least significant (and most rapidly changing) are at the front
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the string to be returned
        Returns:
        the randomly generated string

      • generateRandomID

        public static java.lang.String generateRandomID(KeyableBean bean,
                                int length)
        Generates a random id of the given length. Each character in the id is a int from 0-9
        Parameters:
        bean - an object to use as a seed for the random number generator
        length - the length of the string to be returned
        Returns:
        a random id of the given length

      • renderAsDefaultCurrency

        @Deprecated
public static java.lang.String renderAsDefaultCurrency(java.math.BigDecimal amount)
        Deprecated. (Since 8.0.0) Instead use MonetaryAmounts.render(gw.pl.currency.MonetaryAmount)
        Renders an amount as currency for display. Shortcut for CurrencyUtil.renderAsCurrency(java.math.BigDecimal, gw.pl.currency.typekey.Currency) with the default currency.
        Parameters:
        amount - the number to be converted to a currency string
        Returns:
        the currency display string of the given amount with the default currency

      • conditionalQueryResult

        public static <T extends KeyableBean> IQueryBeanResult<T> conditionalQueryResult(boolean condition,
                                                                 IQueryBeanResult<T> queryResult)
        Allows a query to be evaluated conditionally; if the given condition is true returns the given query result but otherwise returns an empty query result. Mainly used in the UI where you only want to execute a query under certain conditions and want to cheaply return nothing if those conditions do not apply. Note that an IQueryBeanResult does not execute any SQL until it is actually asked to return data, either via an iterator or as a row count, so use of conditionalQueryResult reduces unnecessary database access.
        Parameters:
        condition - if true return the specified query result, if false return an empty query result
        queryResult - query result to be used if the condition is true
        Returns:
        a non null query result
